headline: Tips for staying safe during Cincinnati's significant winter storm
author: WLWT Digital Staff
sentences:
“For those who must travel, please be safe and take it slow, giving yourself plenty of time to get to your destination.”
Hamilton County EMA recommends drivers:
Clear your vehicle of snow and ice before driving
Drive slow and be cautious
Leave plenty of space between you and other cars
Don’t crowd the snowplow trucks
When it comes to planning ahead, Hamilton County EMA recommends having these items on hand:
Water and extra food
Flashlight and batteries
Portable cellphone charger
Extra blankets and warm clothing
First Aid kit
Hygiene products
Before a storm, officials recommend:
Have a plan to move yourself and your family — especially those with special needs.

Major winter storm moves in: Freezing rain, sleet, snow create significant impacts

In an on-air interview with AAA's Kara Hutchins, she says many motorists have opted to stay home during this storm, saying their recommendation is to "Sit this one out, let the road crews get out there and get their work done."

Hutchins adds that if you do need to leave, however, that you give yourself plenty of time to arrive at your destination so you can go slowly and take your time to avoid having to speed.
When it comes to power outages, EMA recommends Duke Energy customers report power outages by texting “OUT” to 57801 or calling 800-543-5599.

After a storm, officials recommend:
Stay away from downed power lines and areas that may be hiding lines, such as floodwater and debris.
